Silicates from volcanic ash are abundant in nearly all continents within 19 degrees of the equator.

I once demolished house in Poland. This particular building was village pub (or inn) built around middle of the 19th century. To my astonishment - it seems that bricks were used only to construct corners, to enforce holes in the building (around windows and doors) and to construct chimney.  Except that - the builders used cheaper material. Local clay. Outside walls were about 80cm thick. Looking from inside the first surface was lime mortar about 1cm thick. Then about 30cm of clay. In the middle of the wall there was about 5cm thick layer of reed (probably for thermal isolation - Polish winters are rather harsh). Then about 40cm of clay. Then reed mats. And the last (outside) layer was made from lime and sand mortar. I was amazed why this mud house did not just melted away during heavy autumn rain.  But it lasted for about 150 years! --- Old villagers told me that there is nothing to be amazed about. They told me that the mud is cheap and available locally. And that the "mud houses" are warm in winter, cold in summer and virtually insect and pest free. ---- It seems that this African guy knows what he is doing! :D

My close ancestors (grandparents and before) built houses out of bricks made from clay, a bit of sand, and either straw or cow dung (finer fibers), as the structure, and then a layer of clean clay on the inside and outside, as humidity isolation. The houses retain the temperature amazingly during summer, and if you fix the cracks with clay every 1-2 springs, it lasts for a lifetime. Inside, the walls are painted with lime mixed with a bit of Copper Sulfate for coloring, and to fight insects.

I meant giving money directly to famine victims as a temporary measure is better than giving them grain. Yes I agree, as long as institutions remain weak and the West provides free food there is no incentive to improve agriculture in arid areas. Billions of dollars allocated to irrigation projects end up in Swiss bank accounts, villas in France etc. But is the people remain ignorant then the political elite can always screw them and then beg for food when the people starve. I agree with you.

cntd... when relief food distorts the markets and suppresses prices, farmers export their surpluses, or cut down on production all together. So you can have a farcical situation where Kenya exported 20,000 tonnes of grain to South Sudan in 2010, the same year 2million Kenyans were starving.

Mix in govt corruption and its all a big joke. Its a complex system of market failures, climate risks and govt incompetence.

Famine in Africa is not a production problem its a poverty problem. Subsistence farmers in arid areas produce only enough to survive, so drought means death. Meanwhile 50miles away the markets are bursting with food and grain... but the hungry peasant has no money to buy this grain - so he dies. 

Relief food is a quick fix, but it negatively distorts the market and discourages production by suppressing prices. Better to give them cash to buy in local markets.

Wow, labour intensive! I've seen it done with a front end loader and a mixing tank attached to a tractor. Put dirt, water and straw in the tank. It has a mixing arm in the tank that is operated when you pull the trailer. Have all your brick forms set up... Hundreds of them. Drive the tractor and tank over the forms, open a shute in the bottom of the tank, mud goes into the brick moulds. Leave to dry for awhile. Remove moulds, repeat.

I think that's a very valid question. Apparently mud structures are pretty durable (some of them are thousands of years old). They can get wet, but will easily dry again when a) the temperature is high and/or b) it doesn't rain for many hours. The water probably doesn't penetrate far into the material. I'd also think that structural protection against rain plays a great role, but there are mud buildings that have no such protection whatsoever (maybe in dry climates?). Worth googleing

flic.kr/p/jJfmr This house is likely made of mud with cement plaster covering it. The cement plaster costs more than the brick. The foundation at the bottom will be cement, so that water doesn't seep up and soften the mud walls during the rainy season.

@ninja2koo 
I'm a Canadian who's lived in Eastern Ghana for many years. Mud brick construction is very common there.
Here's some at flic.kr/p/NPXnf
The one on the right is under construction. You normally build them in the dry season and try to roof them before the rains come in late April. The heaviest rains come without much wind and falls vertically.  You build decent eaves to keep the water away from the walls.
